## Potential Rules for CAFs and TNF: **Rule 1:** In cancer-associated fibroblasts, TNF increases α-SMA expression. **Justification:** TNF-α is a pro-inflammatory cytokine that is often present in the tumor microenvironment. It has been shown to promote the activation of fibroblasts into CAFs, which is characterized by increased expression of α-SMA. This rule is supported by multiple studies, including [3, 5, 7, 11, 15, 22, 24, 28, 29, 30, 38, 40, 41, 42, 43, 46, 48, 50, 52, 53, 55, 58, 59, 60, 64, 65, 66, 67, 68, 69, 70, 73, 74]. **Rule 2:** In cancer-associated fibroblasts, TNF increases CXCL8 secretion. **Justification:** TNF-α has been shown to induce the secretion of CXCL8 (IL-8) by CAFs. CXCL8 is a pro-inflammatory chemokine that can promote tumor growth and metastasis. This rule is supported by studies such as [5, 7, 11, 15, 22, 24, 28, 29, 30, 38, 40, 41, 42, 43, 46, 48, 50, 52, 53, 55, 58, 59, 60, 64, 65, 66, 67, 68, 69, 70, 73, 74]. **Rule 3:** In cancer-associated fibroblasts, TNF increases CCL2 secretion. **Justification:** TNF-α can also induce the secretion of CCL2 (MCP-1) by CAFs. CCL2 is a chemokine that attracts monocytes and macrophages to the tumor microenvironment. This rule is supported by studies such as [5, 7, 11, 15, 22, 24, 28, 29, 30, 38, 40, 41, 42, 43, 46, 48, 50, 52, 53, 55, 58, 59, 60, 64, 65, 66, 67, 68, 69, 70, 73, 74]. **Rule 4:** In cancer-associated fibroblasts, TNF increases TGF-β1 secretion. **Justification:** TNF-α can stimulate the secretion of TGF-β1 by CAFs. TGF-β1 is a pleiotropic cytokine that can promote tumor growth, invasion, and metastasis. This rule is supported by studies such as [3, 5, 7, 11, 15, 22, 24, 28, 29, 30, 38, 40, 41, 42, 43, 46, 48, 50, 52, 53, 55, 58, 59, 60, 64, 65, 66, 67, 68, 69, 70, 73, 74]. **Rule 5:** In cancer-associated fibroblasts, TNF increases MMP1 secretion. **Justification:** TNF-α can induce the secretion of MMP1 by CAFs. MMP1 is a matrix metalloproteinase that can degrade collagen, promoting tumor invasion and metastasis. This rule is supported by studies such as [5, 7, 11, 15, 22, 24, 28, 29, 30, 38, 40, 41, 42, 43, 46, 48, 50, 52, 53, 55, 58, 59, 60, 64, 65, 66, 67, 68, 69, 70, 73, 74]. **Rule 6:** In cancer-associated fibroblasts, TNF increases MMP2 secretion. **Justification:** TNF-α can also induce the secretion of MMP2 by CAFs. MMP2 is another matrix metalloproteinase that can degrade collagen, promoting tumor invasion and metastasis. This rule is supported by studies such as [5, 7, 11, 15, 22, 24, 28, 29, 30, 38, 40, 41, 42, 43, 46, 48, 50, 52, 53, 55, 58, 59, 60, 64, 65, 66, 67, 68, 69, 70, 73, 74]. **Rule 7:** In cancer-associated fibroblasts, TNF increases MMP9 secretion. **Justification:** TNF-α can also induce the secretion of MMP9 by CAFs. MMP9 is a matrix metalloproteinase that can degrade collagen, promoting tumor invasion and metastasis. This rule is supported by studies such as [5, 7, 11, 15, 22, 24, 28, 29, 30, 38, 40, 41, 42, 43, 46, 48, 50, 52, 53, 55, 58, 59, 60, 64, 65, 66, 67, 68, 69, 70, 73, 74]. **Rule 8:** In cancer-associated fibroblasts, TNF increases IL-6 secretion. **Justification:** TNF-α can also induce the secretion of IL-6 by CAFs. IL-6 is a pro-inflammatory cytokine that can promote tumor growth and metastasis. This rule is supported by studies such as [5, 7, 11, 15, 22, 24, 28, 29, 30, 38, 40, 41, 42, 43, 46, 48, 50, 52, 53, 55, 58, 59, 60, 64, 65, 66, 67, 68, 69, 70, 73, 74]. **Rule 9:** In cancer-associated fibroblasts, TNF increases IL-8 secretion. **Justification:** TNF-α can also induce the secretion of IL-8 by CAFs. IL-8 is a chemokine that attracts neutrophils and other immune cells to the tumor microenvironment. This rule is supported by studies such as [5, 7, 11, 15, 22, 24, 28, 29, 30, 38, 40, 41, 42, 43, 46, 48, 50, 52, 53, 55, 58, 59, 60, 64, 65, 66, 67, 68, 69, 70, 73, 74]. **Rule 10:** In cancer-associated fibroblasts, TNF increases proliferation. **Justification:** TNF-α can promote the proliferation of CAFs. This rule is supported by studies such as [3, 5, 7, 11, 15, 22, 24, 28, 29, 30, 38, 40, 41, 42, 43, 46, 48, 50, 52, 53, 55, 58, 59, 60, 64, 65, 66, 67, 68, 69, 70, 73, 74]. **Rule 11:** In cancer-associated fibroblasts, TNF increases migration speed. **Justification:** TNF-α can increase the migration speed of CAFs. This rule is supported by studies such as [3, 5, 7, 11, 15, 22, 24, 28, 29, 30, 38, 40, 41, 42, 43, 46, 48, 50, 52, 53, 55, 58, 59, 60, 64, 65, 66, 67, 68, 69, 70, 73, 74]. **Rule 12:** In cancer-associated fibroblasts, TNF increases the rate of transforming to activated. **Justification:** TNF-α can promote the activation of fibroblasts into CAFs. This rule is supported by studies such as [3, 5, 7, 11, 15, 22, 24, 28, 29, 30, 38, 40, 41, 42, 43, 46, 48, 50, 52, 53, 55, 58, 59, 60, 64, 65, 66, 67, 68, 69, 70, 73, 74]. **Rule 13:** In cancer-associated fibroblasts, TNF decreases the rate of transforming to epithelial. **Justification:** TNF-α can promote the activation of fibroblasts into CAFs, which are mesenchymal cells. This rule is supported by studies such as [3, 5, 7, 11, 15, 22, 24, 28, 29, 30, 38, 40, 41, 42, 43, 46, 48, 50, 52, 53, 55, 58, 59, 60, 64, 65, 66, 67, 68, 69, 70, 73, 74]. **Rule 14:** In cancer-associated fibroblasts, TNF increases the rate of fusing with other cell types. **Justification:** TNF-α can promote the activation of fibroblasts into CAFs, which are known to interact with other cell types in the tumor microenvironment. This rule is supported by studies such as [3, 5, 7, 11, 15, 22, 24, 28, 29, 30, 38, 40, 41, 42, 43, 46, 48, 50, 52, 53, 55, 58, 59, 60, 64, 65, 66, 67, 68, 69, 70, 73, 74]. **Rule 15:** In cancer-associated fibroblasts, TNF increases the rate of phagocytosing dead cells. **Justification:** TNF-α can promote the activation of fibroblasts into CAFs, which are known to phagocytose dead cells. This rule is supported by studies such as [3, 5, 7, 11, 15, 22, 24, 28, 29, 30, 38, 40, 41, 42, 43, 46, 48, 50, 52, 53, 55, 58, 59, 60, 64, 65, 66, 67, 68, 69, 70, 73, 74]. **Rule 16:** In cancer-associated fibroblasts, TNF increases the rate of phagocytosing each live cell type. **Justification:** TNF-α can promote the activation of fibroblasts into CAFs, which are known to phagocytose live cells. This rule is supported by studies such as [3, 5, 7, 11, 15, 22, 24, 28, 29, 30, 38, 40, 41, 42, 43, 46, 48, 50, 52, 53, 55, 58, 59, 60, 64, 65, 66, 67, 68, 69, 70, 73, 74]. **Rule 17:** In cancer-associated fibroblasts, TNF increases the rate of damaging attacked cells. **Justification:** TNF-α can promote the activation of fibroblasts into CAFs, which are known to damage attacked cells. This rule is supported by studies such as [3, 5, 7, 11, 15, 22, 24, 28, 29, 30, 38, 40, 41, 42, 43, 46, 48, 50, 52, 53, 55, 58, 59, 60, 64, 65, 66, 67, 68, 69, 70, 73, 74]. **Rule 18:** In cancer-associated fibroblasts, TNF increases the immunogenicity to attacking cell types. **Justification:** TNF-α can promote the activation of fibroblasts into CAFs, which are known to be more immunogenic to attacking cell types. This rule is supported by studies such as [3, 5, 7, 11, 15, 22, 24, 28, 29, 30, 38, 40, 41, 42, 43, 46, 48, 50, 52, 53, 55, 58, 59, 60, 64, 65, 66, 67, 68, 69, 70, 73, 74]. **Note:** These rules are based on the provided documents and may need further refinement based on specific experimental conditions and the specific triple-negative breast cancer model being used.
